message: Even though the House rushed to vote on #TrumpCare last week, we still don’t have the Congressional Budget Office “score” to tell us the effects. But it’s clear based on earlier versions of the plan that it will take away health coverage from millions of Americans, gut coverage of essential benefits, lead to higher costs, and once again allow discrimination against Americans with pre-existing conditions.   In Del Norte County, you can see the personal impacts of this TrumpCare bill: more than 3,000 of my constituents rely on the health care they receive through the MediCal expansion under the Affordable Care Act and another 600+ have their health costs subsidized by the Affordable Care Act. All of that is at risk from TrumpCare. It’s for these families, and for the seniors whose premiums who would go up, that I voted NO on TrumpCare last week. I’ll keep fighting to protect the health care of my constituents.

The President’s abrupt firing of FBI Director Comey yesterday certainly appears to be an attempt to derail an ongoing investigation, which is just the latest in a series of highly suspicious events surrounding Trump-Russia ties. This bombshell dropped just before my latest town hall yesterday, on the importance of holding the White House accountable, so I was glad to have the opportunity to talk about the news with our panelists and attendees. Today’s news that President Trump and Scott Pruitt are trying to revive the environmentally and economically devastating Pebble Mine is the latest in their egregious handouts to extractive industry, at the expense of the environment, local jobs, and surrounding communities. That’s why the Obama administration put a stop to it, and it’s why the Trump administration is wrong to re-open the idea.

Have you heard of the vaquita? It’s the world’s smallest and most rare marine mammal and is only found in the upper Gulf of California. Due entirely to human-related causes, the vaquita is on the verge of extinction with less than 30 remaining in the wild. Thanks to the cooperative efforts of nonprofit organizations working with the United States and Mexico, a “vaquita CPR” plan is underway, but it may not be enough.   Among other things, Vaquitas die from entanglement in illegal gillnets that are used to capture another endangered animal – the totoaba fish. Without a permanent and effective gillnet ban, this species will likely go extinct by 2018.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/27/world/americas/only-captivity-will-save-the-vaquita-experts-say.html

I’m glad to represent Phyllis Gould in Congress- she has continued to fight tenaciously for Rosie the Riveters across the country. Over the past three years, at Phyllis’ urging, I led my colleagues from across the aisle — and in both the House and the Senate — to propose a National Rosie the Riveter Day to honor the inspiring women who helped the United States win World War II. The changing roles of women in the workforce during the war forced us to look at child care and health care in a new way, and increased the momentum toward equal rights — a fight that continues today. We owe the Rosies a great debt, and must continue to recognize them as the American heroes that they are, which is why I’m so excited that we prevailed in the Senate this year. I introduced the INSPIRE Act this week to renew our commitment to America’s civic engagement and community service. This bill will increase funding, loans, and educational benefits for those who teach in our schools, increase health outcomes in underserved areas, and build up our communities through the Corporation for National and Community Service (CNCS), which includes programs such as Americorps, VISTA, Senior Corps, Foster Grandparents Program, Conservation Corps,  as well as Peace Corps. Especially important is the set-aside to ensure that rural areas benefit from expanded service opportunities. I believe the future of our nation depends on providing more people with the opportunity to use their talents to serve our communities, our planet, and our world. This bill will help more Americans get involved in their communities, and allowing them to serve as a positive example in their communities here at home as well as around the world.

Last night I voted to block an Intelligence authorization bill because House GOP leadership tried to rush it through without considering a single amendment. Later this week we’ll be voting on a defense funding bill that originally included a bipartisan amendment authored by Barbara Lee to require Congress to debate ongoing military conflicts: the authorization of the use of military force. But even though the committee approved her amendment, House Republican leadership removed the amendment without a vote before the bill headed to the House floor. What happened to “regular order” in the House? Shouldn’t Congress be allowed to debate and vote on these important issues?

As is often the case, Elizabeth Warren is right. It’s disappointing that the Senate confirmed Bernhardt- a walking conflict of interest- to help run federal water policy. What happened to the Trump Administration’s promise to drain the swamp?

One of the important civil rights milestones during President Obama’s time in office was the promise that military service would be open to all patriotic Americans who wish to serve their country, including those who are transgender. When President Trump’s Defense Secretary James Mattis delayed that policy, I sent a letter urging him to allow all people to serve.   Today President Trump commemorated the anniversary of President Truman’s commitment, in 1941, to a desegregated military… by deciding to bar transgender individuals from serving in any capacity. This is not about budget savings or social experiments, it’s about Americans who want to serve their country and being blocked by President Trump – who is, meanwhile, cheering billions of dollars in unneeded Pentagon spending and pushing a health care bill that would take health care from hundreds of thousands of veterans.

John Oliver gets it right. We need to roll back corporate media consolidation and prevent monopolies in local media so that no single voice can completely control what communities see and hear. By reviving an antiquated FCC loophole (the so-called “UHF discount”), the Trump Administration wants to allow right-wing media conglomerates to swallow up more stations in local television markets, like in Eureka where Sinclair Media Group could control the majority of news that people can watch on local television, no matter what TV channel they’re watching. That’s why I introduced the Local and Independent Television Protection Act today to ensure that every American has access to a variety of local news sources that report on the local – and national – issues they care most about.

Trumpcare’s collapse in the Senate is a testament to the power of Americans to make their voices heard, and to make their representative government respond. Constituents have emailed or called my office over 7000 times to oppose this lethal bill- with fewer than 200 expressing support- and that’s before you count the thousands of people who came to my town halls.   The dangerous and partisan approach Republican leaders in Congress pursued to rip health insurance away from millions of Americans and make health care more expensive for seniors and families clearly is not the solution to our health care challenges.  Let’s take this historic moment as an opportunity to get serious and innovative in our next steps: to allow every single American to afford high quality health care. That’s why I joined with colleagues yesterday to introduce new Medicare buy-in legislation to take one of our nation’s most successful health programs -- Medicare -- and open it up to millions of Americans. I’m also a long-time supporter of the Medicare For All bill, and of several other proposals to improve the health insurance system, and I’ve written to President Trump asking him to come attend a public congressional forum on health care. Let’s build on these proven health care programs, and scrap this devastating repeal effort once and for all.

Last week, I spoke on the floor of the House of Representatives in opposition to the #GOPtaxscam. The Senate pushed through its version at 2a.m. on Saturday, full of handwritten amendments and without giving Senators anywhere near enough time to actually read it. Between both versions, the tax scam would increase taxes on student loans, eliminate the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act (meaning higher premiums and more people without coverage), repeal the deduction for state and local taxes, and open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. Last week, the House approved a resolution that I cosponsored, mandating yearly anti-harassment and anti-discrimination training for all members of the House, staff, fellows, and interns working in the legislative branch. This bipartisan resolution is an incremental but important step; we also need more transparency and oversight in Congress on these issues, including an end to secret settlements, nondisclosures agreements that have kept victims from telling their stories and protecting others, and the gross misuse of taxpayer dollars we have seen in some of these cases. That’s why I’ll be cosponsoring Rep. Jackie Speier’s broader legislation to overhaul the flawed complaint process here. We have a very long way to go to ensure that everyone is protected from the harassment and abuse that has all too frequently been in the news this year, and of course, these protective steps need to go much further than process and should also be accompanied by a hard reckoning. Those who aspire to serve in public office - and those in every sector of society - must always act with respect and professionalism and to not abuse the power they hold. That's the only way we will end this.
